In the mid-90s (pre-cancer), Armstrong competed in the TdF 4 times with middling results. During this period, the doping was beginning to include EPO, which was brand new and a complete game-changer. Pre-EPO/oxygen doping, the superhuman efforts of the early 2000s by riders who didn't have natural hematocrit levels near 50% or who weren't good enough in the mountains were virtually nonexistent, even with the help of things like corticosteroids. Pre-EPO, Armstrong, while talented and most likely doping in some way, was regularly outclassed in the mountains because he wasn't built to win those stages.

For Armstrong, an EPO/oxygen doping program would help a massively fierce competitor like him remedy his physiological disadvantages much more than it would help a someone with a better physiological starting point.

So what changed in '99? US Postal industrialized the doping, implementing a team-wide, EPO-based doping program systematically designed to decimate the competition, rather than just to keep pace. Tyler Hamilton's book explains how the entire pro peloton was caught flat-footed in '99, having brought the equivalent of knives to the Postal's machine guns in the 1999-01 tours. It was only when the others adapted the Postal blueprint were they able to make it respectable in later Armstrong-era tours.

In the cycling community, the chicken-egg question is pretty settled. Armstrong always took it a step further, forcing everyone else to keep up.

Sasha, you lost me at "One thing is for sure. . ." How do you know?

Otherwise, good note.

"But in Armstrong’s case, they are connected. If he does not cheat, he presumably does not dominate the Tour de France;"

Since this commentary is about logical connections, I would just point out that virtually all of Lance's primary competitors, aka team leaders in the TdF, had already been caught doping, that's why so many suspected Lance. If he crushed his dirty competition, how could he be clean?

If Lance had not cheated, AND, if his competitors had not cheated as well, then it's quite possible Lance still would have dominated the TdF. Which of course raises the chicken-or-egg conundrum, did Lance cheat to level the playing field, or did the competitors cheat to keep up with Lance? I think most cycling observers would say that doping was endemic in the sport long before Lance became dominant.

Mr. Underwood, as someone who's received stock awards in the past I'd like to clarify your misconception of how their taxation works. Stock grants by companies to their employees are taxed as ordinary income when they vest. Campbell's CEO owes 35% on those stock awards. She'll owe 35% on any additional appreciation on that stock she holds less than a year, 15% if she holds more than a year.

Raising the capital gains tax rate will not raise taxes on stock grants.

Take a look at how the capital gains tax works for those who's salaries are in the millions. Just got the 10K from Campbell Soup:

Denise Morrison's Salary is $950K & stock awards are $5,067,264. She pays regular tax on the salary. Sells the stock in 12 months and pays 15% tax on the gains.

Then there are the grand children of the founder. They own:

Bennett Dorrance 46,362,107 shares
Mary Alice D Malone 53,118,146 shares
The dividend is $1.16 a share per year.
46362107X1.16=53,780,011.4/365=$147,342.58 a day income
on which B Dorrance pays a 15% tax of $8,067001.60 a year.

I hold not grudge against Mr. Dorrance but he is just one example of the 1% who pay a lower tax rate than your local auto mechanic. True he pays a tax which is more than 90% of people will make in their life time, so yes he and others do pay more into the treasury. However as you can see, another 10% in taxes will not put him in the poor house. He might have to wait two days to buy a new Ferrari.

Then go to the Forbes 400 notice the Walton heirs, and the Cargill heirs, they make the Dorrance's look like poor people.

Also the tax increase is for dividend and capital gains on income over $250K, not on salaries and interest. You pay ordinary income on interest from corporate bonds.
The reference to the small business owners is a red herring.

Tom: I too worked for many years in financial services - with American Express. While your suggestion to consumers to carry no balance at the end of the month is indeed a healthy alternative, it is important to remember the greed and impunity in which these financial institutions operate.

You may recall 10 years ago the big push by the banks was to reward their customers with lower fees if they automated their banking services - eliminated paper transactions. Once most of the customers complied the banks realized they had lost a revenue stream (due to lower fees). So...now they are charging for...automated transactions! The same happened when customers willfully reduced the number of transactions on their credit cards in an effort to control their spending. Now banks are charging a fee if a customer does not have "x" number of transactions per month.

I assure you, that if more customers decide not to carry a balance on their cards, banks will start assessing a fee by charging for the card.

Our economy (more so than any other), and our form of "free market" is driven strictly by greed and financial institutions shoulder that responsibility by pushing consumers toward the mentality that the bank wants them in. Our financial institutions have...no conscience whatsoever.

The best solution is that consumers revert back to cash. Period. Of course, then the banks will charge merchants and consumers for using cash instead of plastic. No win anywhere!

My husband has early onset Alzheimers starting at age 62. He is now 65... His brother recently passed away with Frontal Lobe Dementia at 59. He has had Amyvid Scan and MRI's.
We haved tried Aricept and Namenda with no improvement. Is there anything else we can do ? Can anything be done to help prevent our children from getting this disease?
Good question.

Why don't doctors take more care excluding thyroid disease and B12 before pronouncing Alzheimer's disease? Young doctors from the better schools understand that they should test free T3 and free T4 as well as TSH, and are aware of the role of reverse T3, and use the narrower lab range, but many doctors still don't get it.

You may have heard that Japan uses 550 pg/mL as it's bottom threshold on it's lab range for B12, yet we let millions suffer because of stubbornness or ignorance. B12 deficiency needlessly devastates too many people who get misdiagnosed with Alzheimer's because of lack of awareness. At the very least, a homocystine and MMA test should be taken.

All these should be repeated regularly as well, for the first year, at least. The Framingham Offspring study shows that it would save countless lives, and a whole lot of misery and money.We
That's why Buddy Ryan punched Gilbride out during a game on national TV and called his play-calling philosophy "chuck and duck."

I don't know which Giants fans you've been listening to. Not this one. Gilbride has driven me crazy for years because he's too aggressive, not too conservative. (The idea that the Giants have ever been a run-focused team under Coughlin is ridiculous, and the repetition of that theme by analysts shows how little they prepare. At times they put up good rushing stats but it's run enabled by the pass, not vice versa.)

This is Gilbride:
1. First down....pass.
2. If first down incomplete and it's second and 10...run.
3. If distance is 10+ on any down....screen.
4. 2nd or 3rd and less than 2.....deep pass.
5. Red zone...shotgun runs, or pass plays that are completed but not in the end zone.
6. Goal line...try at at least useless fade route.
7. Most complex or very deep route play action calls come on the first down of a series or out of a timeout (i.e., only when Gilbride has 3 minutes to stare at his sheet)

#s 3-5 are all done because he wants to do the most unpredictable thing. The problem is, when you do the most unpredictable thing EVERY TIME, it's predictable, not unpredictable.

Aggressive playcallers are only effective if they are sensitive to the game context and unpredictable - Gilbride is neither.

Gilbride hurts Eli. Gilbride hurts the defense - no regard for getting a couple first downs when the D needs a breather. Gilbride gives the O-Line a bad name - the D usually knows what's coming.

PS - I don't like Gilbride.

I think Mr. Boehner will need to be reminded frequently that Mr. Romney lost the election and that a majority of Americans rejected Mr. Ryan's budget proposal.

As I understand Republican ideology, tax cuts to the wealthy puts more money in the hands of "job creators," allowing money in the form of jobs to trickle down to the rest of us. Yet Mr. Boehner is proposing a cut in tax rates that are paid for in the end of tax expenditures, such as the morgtage deduction. If in the end, the wealthy are paying just as much as they were before in tax reform, how does that generate jobs in the Republican world?

In his speech to us all today he cited a couple of studies that claim raising taxes would harm the economy. What he refuses to acknowledge is that the OBM's study states that raising taxes on those with high incomes will not have a depressive effect. And his own Congressional study shows that cutting taxes on the wealthy does not create jobs.

What will it take to drag Mr. Boehner into a fact-based world?

While Mr. Boehner is confronting reality, the rest of us need to remember that the world will not end if the Bush tax cuts end and defense spending is cut. However, the world will end for millions of Americans if Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid are significantly altered.

I don't think the Dems will give up the center so easily as Clinton yanked it out from under the Republicans. They need to start educating the public now so that in 2014 they can act like Democrats instead of conservative lites.

What I am struck by in Silver's analysis are the number of states that the Republican party will never, ever win again. Even with a dramatic shift to the center (which isn't happening), they will still be The Answer-lite, and any major shift by the Republicans will be matched by a much more progressive Democratic caucus.

This is fairly easy to understand in the parlance of modern politics: If someone tries to take your position, you go further away to a position that they find unacceptable, and party there. Capitulation is never met with Acquiescence to the other sides position, or even further. No. If the Republicans attempt to move Left, so do the Democrats.

And with that, looking at that distribution and taking anything over 11 points for Obama, that totals 179 electoral votes. Those states are essentially almost off the board for Republicans for a considerable amount of time, at least two to three cycles. Taking 11 < x < 6, which now are relatively safe for one to two cycles, that's 54 more votes, for 233.

Any calculus that comes out having the Dems having any less than this, for the next two elections, is questionable. This is a base level. This is what Republicans have to fight against. A margin of error that is so small as to force some kind of hand. Because from 6 < x < 2, there's another 52 votes, totaling 285, well over 270 to feel comfortable, without even considering OH or FL. You can bet Dems are also gonna spend a lot of time in NC. Bleak GOP future ahead.
